Title: WDC/WCC - Leisure Development Programme (Kenilworth) - AWARD
Description:
Warwick District Council requires project management and full design team services (as listed in the Contract Particulars) for the next phase of the Leisure Development Programme (LDP), which will comprise works at the Castle Farm Recreation Centre and Abbey Fields Swimming Pool. Both centres are located in Kenilworth, Warwickshire.
       
      Warwick District Council has managed the LDP since 2013. The first phase of the programme, after an appropriate and detailed scoping exercise, was the refurbishment and extension of Newbold Comyn and St Nicholas Park Leisure Centres, in a project costing £16 million.
       
      Phase Two of the LDP is the refurbishment and extension and/or replacement of the Council's two leisure centres in Kenilworth - the Abbey Fields Swimming Pool and Castle Farm Recreation Centre. At present there are a number of different opportunities identified for both buildings. Both sites offer a number of significant opportunities and restraints. The Supplier will evaluate what options are appropriate for each of the buildings, and carry out an options appraisal which recommends specific options to the Council for consideration.
       
      The Abbey Fields Swimming Pool currently contains a 25 metre indoor swimming pool; a free-form outdoor swimming pool; a free-form outdoor paddling pool; separate male and female changing rooms; a sauna and a café area with internal and external serving hatches.  The area under consideration in this project includes 5 outdoor tennis courts and a disused sports pavilion near to the swimming pool.
       
      Castle Farm Recreation Centre contains a four badminton court main hall; a 28 station gym; a small meeting room; changing rooms for indoor and outdoor sport and a vending area. The first floor of the building is currently occupied by the local District Scout Association.
       
      The Supplier will be selected by mini-competition under the Crown Commercial Services procurement process RM3741 (Lot 1).
       
      The Supplier is to act as the Project Lead for Phase Two in the delivery of the refurbishment, extension and/or replacement of the leisure centres on these two sites. The Supplier is to coordinate the project from RIBA Stage 0 to RIBA Stage 7.

Title: DfT Group Facilities Management Service Model Project Manager Remit
Description:
In accordance with the terms and conditions of Lot 1 of the Ministry of Justice Strategic Alliance Agreement PSP Framework, the Department for Transport (DfT) invites a proposal for the Project Management role to procure, mobilise and embed steady-state operations for the DfT Facilities Management Service. 

The Department’s Group Property Board lead on property matters across DfT and Agencies.  Property matters on five themes are coordinated through the Property Group Operating Model, with one theme being Facilities Management (FM).  The general principle is for all parties to coordinate, share best practice, and to seek efficiencies by acting as one and aggregating activity, resources and spend.
The DfT Group has four principal Total Facilities Management (TFM) contracts, plus a collection of smaller arrangements in-place for BTP.  The proposal is to replace all of these with a single contracted FM model (‘The Service Model’) to serve all estates.  The contract(s) are to be procured from the mandated CCS FM Framework ; that is one procurement for many.
The Government Property Shared Services Programme (PSSP) has allied The Department with DEFRA.  DEFRA is constrained under their current FM provision until 2024, yet one of their agencies (The Environment Agency) is available to join subject to internal governance and Cabinet Office approvals.
This remit is to harness the scarce professional FM resource across the department and to project manage the successful delivery of The Service Model through to steady-state operations.

Title: New Student Centre for University College London
Description:
The New Student Centre project demonstrates UCL’s com¬mitment to students and will provide outstanding facilities that enhance the student experience. The brief calls for a highly sustainable new building that is distinctive, with exceptional design quality, reflecting UCL’s global significance whilst not appearing elitist. It should be a building that is accessible, inclusive, and welcoming. 

The New Student Centre will provide two primary functions: student learning space and a Student Enquiries Centre.  A range of student learning spaces are required, and the building will provide ‘social’ spaces including a cafe as well as space for exhibitions.  The learning spaces will vary in character and size, creating different types of individual study and group collabora¬tion settings.  None of the spaces will be used for formal teaching.  Dedicated to the needs of the students, the building will deliver spaces and furniture solutions that are flexible, adaptable, and IT resourced, with effective power provision. 

Flanked by listed buildings, the new building will occupy a central campus site within the Bloomsbury Conservation area.  The site is a prime entrance to UCL’s Bloomsbury campus and is used extensively by both pedestrians and vehicles.  The project includes demolition of part of the adjacent Bloomsbury Theatre to enhance the circulation routes around and through the new building.  The building will comprise four floor levels above the ground floors, and 2 levels of basement.
